The disc opens with the single of the album of the same name, which has a very catchy rhythm and a text that at first listen seem trivial, but in reality, a photographer perfectly Italy of that period. The second track is "Mestieri che si inventano" a true ballad, praising precisely, the so-called trades that are invented, such as the songwriter. "Allora chi" is another piece-suit against the company at that time (which looks pretty darn today's society), very rock and Bennato with a more biting tone than ever. "Era una festa" is probably the most useless piece of the album. Legend has it, that it was dedicated to his friend Francesco De Gregori and in fact, in the text, a "Francesco" appears.

Continuing in listening, comes "La citta' Obliqua", a very sweet ballad, which, as you can easily guess from the title, is a kind of homage-complaint, the city of Naples. And behold, "Tu vuoi l' America." Quet'ultima is one of the most beloved songs and discussed by Bennato, the "usual" someone says that it represents the passage of the singer-songwriter genre commercial (which then will result in the success of "Viva La Mamma"), instead of someone else loves it madness. I think it's just a beautiful love song and I think that sometimes there is no need to make treaties of philosophy, to talk about love. To close the album include: "Chi Beve-Chi Beve", another song the funny and sincere about the city of Naples and "La Televisione Che FilicitÃƒÂ ," in which Bennato, inveighs against the TV (and to think that reality shows do not exist yet ).
